content.text:
(Suggested reading time—15 minutes)
(Suggested writing time—40 minutes)
(This question counts for one-third of the total essay section score.)
War seems to be an inevitable part of the human experience. Depending on the circumstances, war is considered ennobling, necessary, and just. However, it may also be seen as corrupt, irrational, or even evil. Must war be an unavoidable part of human civilization? Is the sacrifice of war worth it? Do the casualties outweigh the causes?
Read the following sources (including any introductory information) carefully. Then develop a position about what issues should be considered most important in making the decision to declare war.
Make sure that your argument is central; use the sources to illustrate and support your reasoning. Avoid merely summarizing the sources. Indicate clearly which sources you are drawing from, whether through direct quotation, paraphrase, or summary. You may cite the sources as Source A, Source B, etc., or by using the descriptions in parentheses. Source A (Wilson)
Source B (Henry)
Source C (Kennedy)
Source D (Bush)
Source E (Reagan)
Source F (Department of Veterans Affairs)
Source G (Department of Defense)

content.correctText: Sample Answer: Prepare an argument answering these questions: Is war necessary, and what issues should we think about before going to war?

content.text:
The struggle for equal rights for women in the United States began long before the nation existed, and some would argue that this struggle continues even today. While most people would agree that men and women should have equal rights, many citizens fail to realize the complexity and scope of the inequality that women endure.
Read the following sources carefully. In a well-organized essay, take a position on the relevance of the women’s rights struggle to the overall cultural prosperity of the United States.
Make sure that your argument is central; use the sources to illustrate and support your reasoning. Avoid merely summarizing the sources. Indicate clearly which sources you are drawing from, whether through direct quotation, paraphrase, or summary. You may cite the sources as Source A, Source B, etc., or by using the descriptions in parentheses. Source A (Jones)
Source B (Wollstonecraft)
Source C (Schlafly)
Source D (Peters)
Source E (Bureau of Labor Statistics)

scene.credits: (tr)C Squared Studios/Getty Images; (bkgd)Grant Faint/Photographer's Choice/Getty Images.

multiple.question: Which sentence is the task?

figure.text: (1)The struggle for equal rights for women in the United States began long before the nation existed, and some would argue that this struggle continues even today. (2) While most people would agree that men and women should have equal rights, many citizens fail to realize the complexity and scope of the inequality that women endure. (3) Read the following sources carefully. (4) In a well-organized essay, take a position on the relevance of the women’s rights struggle to the overall cultural prosperity of the United States.

content.text:
—From an address by J. Elizabeth Jones, The Salem, Ohio, 1850 Women’s Rights Convention Proceedings
“There is not, perhaps, in the wide field of reform, any one subject so difficult to discuss as that of Woman’s Rights. I use the term “Woman’s Rights” because it is a technical phrase. I like not the expression. It is not Woman’s Rights of which I design to speak, but of Woman’s Wrongs. I shall claim nothing for ourselves because of our sex—I shall demand the recognition of no rights on the ground of our womanhood. In the contest which is now being waged in behalf of the enslaved colored man in this land, I have yet to hear the first word in favor of his rights as a colored man; the great point which is sought to be established is this, that the colored man is a human being, and as such, entitled to the free exercise of all the rights which belong to humanity. And we should demand our recognition as equal members of the human family. . . .”

scene.credits: (tr)C Squared Studios/Getty Images; (bkgd)Grant Faint/Photographer's Choice/Getty Images.
(tr)C Squared Studios/Getty Images; (bkgd)Grant Faint/Photographer's Choice/Getty Images.

content.text:
—From Mary Wollstonecraft's Vindication of the Rights of Women, 1792. Wollstonecraft was a British philosopher and activist. She believed women were not inferior to men, but only lacking in education.
“To render mankind more virtuous, and happier of course, both sexes must act from the same principle; but how can that be expected when only one is allowed to see the reasonableness of it? To render also the social compact truly equitable, and in order to spread those enlightening principles, which alone can meliorate the fate of man, women must be allowed to found their virtue on knowledge, which is scarcely possible unless they be educated by the same pursuits as men. For they are now made so inferiour by ignorance and low desires, as not to deserve to be ranked with them; or, by the serpentine wrigglings of cunning they mount the tree of knowledge and only acquire sufficient to lead men astray.”

scene.credits: (tr)C Squared Studios/Getty Images; (bkgd)Grant Faint/Photographer's Choice/Getty Images.

content.text:
—Phyllis Schlafly, “The Fraud of the Equal Rights Amendment” (1972), from “The Phyllis Schlafly Report,” Volume 5, February 1972. Schlafly is a conservative activist who opposed the Equal Rights Amendment.

“The claim that American women are downtrodden and unfairly treated is the fraud of the century. The truth is that American women never had it so good. Why should we lower ourselves to “equal rights” when we already have the status of special privilege?

This [Equal Rights] Amendment will absolutely and positively make women subject to the draft.”
Reprinted from The Phyllis Schlafly Report, Feb. 1972.

scene.credits: (tr)C Squared Studios/Getty Images; (bkgd)Grant Faint/Photographer's Choice/Getty Images.

(tr)C Squared Studios/Getty Images; (bkgd)Grant Faint/Photographer's Choice/Getty Images.

content.text: The identity of any society revolves around its treatment of its citizens. As time progresses, society must re-evaluate this treatment in order to ensure that each citizen has an opportunity to achieve fulfillment. The United States struggles with this evaluation of identity in the realm of women’s rights. Since the country’s inception, the U.S. has dealt with victories and failures as its leaders and citizenry seek to establish just treatment for all members of the society. The success or failure of the fair and equal treatment of women in the United States will determine the society’s ultimate identity. The journey of the United States toward just treatment of all citizens must encompass an understanding of the history of inequality in order to appreciate the larger context of the struggle and move toward meaningful and relevant change. The struggle for women’s rights is not a new struggle; for centuries, women have understood that their identity within society was tenuous at best. Elizabeth Jones, in her address to a women’s rights convention in 1850, tackles the issue of equality by demanding that women be recognized as “equal members of the human family” (A). Jones’s views in 1850, while vehemently stated, were not extreme for her time period. In fact, almost a century earlier, Mary Wollstonecraft extols similar sentiments in Vindication of the Rights of Women, exclaiming that “women must be allowed to found their virtue of knowledge . . . educated by the same pursuits as men” (B). Obviously, the issue of women’s rights is not restricted merely to the distant past and is, in fact, a fight taking place across the country’s history. Most recently, women endure wages far below their male counterparts (E). Through evaluating the role of this issue in the country’s larger cultural development, we can appreciate the greater need for real and lasting change as a way to provide fulfillment for all citizens.

scene.credits: (tr)C Squared Studios/Getty Images; (bkgd)Grant Faint/Photographer's Choice/Getty Images.

multiple.question: The synthesis essay is most like which of the following essay types?
The synthesis essay requires that you do research.
Each source provided for the synthesis essay will provide contextual information.
The introduction page of the synthesis prompt will contain all of the following EXCEPT

answers.answer: instructions on how many sources to use.

multiple.question: What are the three parts of the synthesis prompt?
The synthesis essay requires that you use all of the provided sources.
The sources for the synthesis essay may contain bias.
The synthesis essay requires that you pick the correct point of view from the prompt.
How much quoted material from the sources should you include in your essay?

answers.answer: As much as needed to summarize information from prompt
Most of the essay should be quotations

multiple.question: Which of the following is NOT a strategy to avoid plagiarism?

answers.answer: Do not rely too much on a single source.
Change a few words from the source.
Cite all ideas that are not your own.
Use quotations when providing information from a source.
Rely on analysis of the material rather than summary.

scene.credits: (tr)C Squared Studios/Getty Images; (bkgd)Grant Faint/Photographer's Choice/Getty Images.
